data.text:
By Claire Prechtel-Kluskens, J.D.(See Footnote*)

Reproduced with permission from the

National Genealogical Society Quarterly, Vol. 85, No. 4 (Dec. 1997): 295-311.

Updated February 5, 2000.

Documenting civilian service during wartime can pose daunting challenges. A family's oral traditions may not include information about nonmilitary service. Even when a civilian role is recalled or referenced in a local history, finding documentary evidence may be difficult and tedious. Federal personnel records for civilians of the nineteenth century, for example, are fragmented--arranged by agency, thereunder by major subdivision of the agency, thereunder by time period, and thereunder in whatever manner each agency kept its records.(See Footnote 1) Time periods vary, as do the types of surviving records.(See Footnote 2) Once located, these records seldom yield family information, but they do provide details of one aspect of an individual's life.(See Footnote 3) Wagonmaster Records This article reproduces a list of civilian wagonmasters who served the Union during the Civil War. The data come from 101 typewritten, three-by-five-inch cards created by the Office of the Quartermaster General and maintained by the National Archives and Records Administration [NARA], Washington, D.C.(See Footnote 4) The date of preparation is unknown, but the file probably originated in the first two decades of the twentieth century, at which time the federal government (and particularly the military establishment) slowly converted from manuscript to typewritten material.(See Footnote 5) Although NARA's preliminary inventory of Quartermaster General records calls these men "wagonmasters and forage masters," the cards do not use the latter term. What they do provide is the name of each wagonmaster, his commanding officer, the station at which he served, and (for most) the year of service--generally 1862-65, but occasionally 1866-67. Cards for surnames beginning with I and J are not extant. The names are arranged in rough alphabetical order by the first letter of the wagonmaster's surname, and thereunder--to a limited extent--by the name of his officer. Some men appear more than once under various abbreviations of the first name or variant spellings of the surname. Editorial Conventions In transcribing this list, certain editorial changes have been made:

Wagonmasters' names appear here in strict alphabetical order, for ease of use.(See Footnote 6)

An asterisk denotes men listed twice with the same officer, station, and year.

Obvious misspellings of place names are corrected--such as Acqua for Aquia Creek (Virginia), Duvall for DeValls Bluff (Arkansas), and Vicksbury for Vicksburg (Mississippi).

Periods replace question marks where it is obvious that the typist accidentally held down the shift key to produce a question mark instead of a period.

Typing errors such as 1965 instead of 1865 are corrected.

References to "Wash., D.C.," and the like are standardized to D.C. References to New Creek ("Va." and "W. Va.") are standardized as W. V. For well-known sites (Harpers Ferry, Little Rock, Memphis, Nashville, Richmond, St. Louis, Vicksburg), state names are deemed unnecessary.

The word Fort, which is variously rendered Ft. and Fort, is abbreviated in this article.

The names of five particular officers, varyingly spelled, have been standardized as C. M. Brazee, C. H. Irvin, M. I. Ludington, C. G. Sawtelle, and G. Tallmadge.(See Footnote 7)

Other records Although the cards do not provide personal or family data, they offer a starting point for further research. One should bear in mind that the records relating to the civilian employee may appear in documents filed under the name of the commanding officer. While it is difficult to predict which other records of the National Archives may contain useful information, the following series from Record Group [RG] 92, Office of the Quartermaster General, are possibilities.(See Footnote 8) Research Tips Of all the above series, Series 238, Reports of Persons and Articles Hired, 1818-1905, is the mother lode of documentation for civilian quartermaster employees. This would be a natural starting point for further research, after first consulting its index in Series 228. For wagonmasters employed in 1861 (who do not appear in the card list transcribed for this article) supplemental help might appear in Entry 240, Record of Personal Services, 1861. As the search proceeds, information on the commanding officer's career might be found in several places--particularly his compiled military service record (RG 94, Records of the Adjutant General's Office) and possible pension file (RG 15, Records of the Veterans Administration), as well as, perhaps, other record series in RG 94. Any of this material might be useful for pinning down the date span during which the officer was stationed at a particular place and, by extension, delimiting the time period during which the civilian wagonmaster could have been employed at that station by that officer. In general, it is often possible to document an ancestor's civilian service during wartime, although particular cases may prove difficult. As with all genealogical research, the essentials for success are patience, persistence, imagination, and a good understanding of available records.

She thanks Michael P. Musick for helpful comments on a draft of this article. Footnote 1. For a better understanding of the arrangement of archival materials, see T. R. Schellenberg, "Archival Principles of Arrangement," in Maygene F. Daniels and Timothy Walch, eds., A Modern Archives Reader: Basic Readings on Archival Theory and Practice (Washington: National Archives, 1984), 157-86. Foonote 2. See, for example, references to various lists of civilian employees in the Office of the Quartermaster General in Maizie H. Johnson, "Preliminary Inventory of the Textual Records of the Office of the Quartermaster General (Record Group 92), Part I," unpublished inventory no. NM-81, May 1967, National Archives-Washington, D.C. Footnote 3. For more information about this type of research, see Claire Prechtel-Kluskens, "Documenting the Career of Federal Employees," Prologue: Quarterly of the National Archives 26 (Summer 1994): 180-85. Footnote 4. The file is designated entry 1164, "List of Wagonmasters and Forage Masters Serving During the Civil War, n.d.," in Johnson, "Preliminary Inventory . . . Quartermaster General," 135. To verify that these men were indeed civilian employees, the author searched NARA microfilm publication T288, General Index to Pension Files, 1861-1934, for six men with unusual names--Ignatius Allison, Whitefield Baird, Garrett Broadhead, Pomeroy Brink, Green Durham, and Voorhees Harris--and found none listed. Footnote 5. The Remington Company put the first reliable typewriter on the market in 1873, but the federal government was slow to adopt the new office technology. On 12 February 1895, the congressional Joint Commission on Laws Organizing Executive Departments-commonly called the Cockrell-Dockery Commission-recommended that the executive departments cease making handwritten copies of correspondence in favor of typed copies with carbons. This recommendation was not immediately acted upon; for example, the War Department's Office of the Chief of Ordnance was considered more progressive than other bureaus when it converted in 1903. In 1913, the Commission on Economy and Efficiency-commonly called the Taft Commission-complained that within the Adjutant General's Office, "communications of the same type . . . have been written thousands of times in this office, and a printed form could be used with a saving of most of the time taken to prepare this communication. Nonetheless the handwritten draft is submitted for approval." For the Remington typewriter, see Charles Singer et al., eds., A History of Technology, vol. 5, The Late Nineteenth Century, c. 1850-c. 1900 (London: Oxford University Press, 1967), 689. For Joint Commission on Laws Organizing Executive Departments, see References to Laws Organizing Executive Departments and Other Government Establishments at the National Capital, Appendix [Report No. 16], 53d Congress, 1st session, Senate Report 41 (serial 3148), U.S. Serial Set [congressional documents, 1789-1969] microfiche (Washington: U.S. Congress, 1969-). For "progressiveness" of the Chief of Ordnance, see Mabel E. Deutrich, "History of the Decimal Filing System in the War Department," National Archives Seminar [Paper] on Recordkeeping Practices, 14 September 1956, MS, National Archives Library, National Archives at College Park, Maryland. For Taft Commission, see Message of the President of the United States Transmitting the Reports of the Commission on Economy and Efficiency, 62d Congress, 3d session, House Document 1252 (serial 6470), p. 133 (quote), also 98-102. Footnote 6. A fundamental principle of record extraction, of course, is to leave entries in their original order-lest inherent clues be obscured. In the present case, however, the original arrangement of the names is an arbitrary one, with no links that would be lost by perfecting the alphabetization. Footnote 7. C. M. Brazee (var. C. H.) was Lt. C. M. Brazee; see his listings in vol. 3 [1863]: 16, of Entry 228, Reporting Officer Index to Part (1861-94) of Series 238; RG 92, Records of the Office of the Quartermaster General; National Archives. C. H. Irvin (var. Irwin and Irvine) was Charles H. Irvin, who mustered out 6 March 1867 as a brevet colonel in the Quartermaster General's Office. See Francis B. Heitman, Historical Register and Dictionary of the United States Army from Its Organization, September 29, 1789 to March 2, 1903 (Washington: Government Printing Office, 1903), 564; also available as 57th Cong., 2d sess., H. Doc. 446, Serials 4535-4536. M. I. Ludington (var. M. I. Luddington, M. J. Ludington, and M. J. Luddington) was Marshall Indepen-dence Ludington, who retired on 13 April 1903 as a major general in the Quartermaster General's Office. See Heitman, Historical Register, 646. C. G. Sawtelle (var. C. J. and J. G. Sawtelle) was Charles Greene Sawtelle, who retired on 16 February 1897 as a brigadier general in the Quartermaster General's Office; see Heitman, Historical Register, 862. G. Tallmadge (var. G. Talmage, G. Talmadge, Grier Talmadge, and G. Tallmage) was Grier Tallmadge, who became a captain assistant quartermaster on 17 May 1861 and died 11 October 1862. See Heitman, Historical Register, 944. Footnote 8. The author has not attempted to research any of the wagonmasters listed and cannot guarantee that additional information on any man can be located in any of these record series.
